segments.text: This is true.
That happens very regularly.
It does with anthropologists, too.

When you're working with informants, you get a guy who's just great, you know, and spouting stuff this way and the other way, and you switch on the tape recorder, and all of a sudden you begin to get these awful stills
Which I will shortly demonstrate.

I know you, from your letters, which you might want to forget, but I know you were in Cincinnati for a while, perhaps grew up there, but if you'd just briefly run down your early history until, say, you got up to UT, it would help out a good deal, I think.
Well, first of all, maybe I ought to say this, that I don't really want to forget those letters.

they they're kind of embarrassing to go back and read now but after all you know you you can't be held responsible for everything you said when you were 14 years old but they meant a great deal to me at one period in my life because i was a kid i was i was nuts about sports and things of that kind i was very active up until i got rheumatic fever when i was a child
And I was very sick, and I was sick for a long time.
And all I had were books.
I used to lie up in my bed in a second story house and look out the window and see all these kids going down to play ball and everything.
And I couldn't go with them.
All I had were the books and the magazines and these letters that I wrote.
And I can remember just the desperate anxiety of waiting for that magazine to come out and find out, had your letter appeared in print?
And it just made my day.
And I really think it would be pretty ungrateful to go back now and say, well, it's just a mistake of my youth and all that.
Because silly as they were, they were in court.
Well, this isn't answering the question.
I never answered questions.
Let's see.
You were in Cincinnati when you started writing letters.
Well, I was born.
Maybe we can begin there.
I was born in Cincinnati on the 30th of March in 1928.
My father was a doctor, a surgeon.
My mother had been a nurse.
She met my father when she was a nurse, he was a doctor, and the full process of time I appeared.
I was still living in Cincinnati at the time I first discovered science fiction.
Actually, I had discovered it, if that's the word, and read it long before I knew what it was.
I read Jules Verne, I can remember, along about the fourth grade, something of that sort, and thought it was great.
And then I hit H.G.
Wells.
Actually, the way I got to reading science fiction, per se, was I was at Burroughs, and I'd read everything that Edgar Rice Burroughs ever wrote, I think.
I particularly was knocked out by the Martian stories.
I guess everybody would.
I often thought, you know, I think everybody did the same thing.
You know, you read A Princess of Mars, and that wonderful technique by which he gets to Mars.
You know, he just goes out and looks yearningly up there at the red planet, and there he is.
I'm sure every kid that ever read Burroughs tried that.
I've often thought how, what an utter disaster it would have been if it worked.
You know, and you suddenly woke up, you know, weak, pimply, 13-year-old boy, you know, standing there on Mars, you know, surrounded by all these God-awful things.
But anyway, I read a lot of Burroughs, and got a letter from him one time, by the way.
He was kind enough to answer a letter that I wrote.
And I went to a newsstand one time.
I don't know how much tape you got on this thing.
Oh, I've got plenty.
You've got plenty.
I'm going to flip it here in a minute.
Well, let me just back up a little bit.
I was always an omnivorous reader.
And chiefly in those days, what I was reading, aside from every book I could get my hands on, were pulp magazines.
And I read them all.
Well, not all of them, but most of them.
And I subscribed to G8 and his Battle Aces and Daredevil Aces and The Spider and The Shadow and Doc Savage and all this stuff.
My pet was G8.
And, you know, looking back now, I can see why.
Because if you've ever read, you've never read G8 and his Battle Aces by Robert J. Hogan.
Well, they were terrific.
They had a wild Baroque.
imagination to them, and they're really science fiction stories, but they weren't presented that way.
Anyway, one time I went to the newsstand and I saw one of those big fat old Amazings, and I don't remember the date.

Well, I don't remember what it was, but it had a Burroughs story in it that was listed on the cover, and I picked it up to read the Burroughs story, and then I made the fatal mistake of reading the rest of the magazine.
And I remember in that issue they had a Neander Bender story in it.
Adam Link Saves the World, I think was the title of it.
And a great short novel by Edmund Hamilton called Treasure on Thunder Moon, which I thought at the time was doubtless the finest piece of literature I'd ever read.
Anyway, I was just completely hooked.
And that's how it happened.
I really did the kind of junk that I described in the letter.
you know, hopping on the bicycle and barreling back to the newsstand and buying everything that had anything to do with science fiction.
It really happened.
It happened every month.
So, anyway, there I was in Cincinnati, and the way I got out of Cincinnati was during the war, as I said, my father was a doctor, and he enlisted, and they sent him to Crystal City, Texas.
as medical officer in charge of what they called an alien detention camp.
There was an internment camp for Japanese and Germans.
And needless to say, he took the family with me, with him.
And when I got to Crystal City, I was a sophomore in high school.
It was the end of my sophomore year in high school.
And so that gets me out of Cincinnati and into Texas.
Now where do you want me to go from there?
You ended up in Kerrville, then.
I stayed with my family in Crystal City through my junior year in high school.
That must have been 44, that sounds right.

Then my father was transferred to Galveston to the Marine Hospital, and I stayed in Crystal City after the family left and rented a room there and stayed, because every time I moved I got ineligible to play football.
And football was the big thing in my life.
I wasn't about to miss my senior year, so I stayed there another year.
Then after I graduated in August 45, I came to the university, but my family was living in Galveston.
And then we left Galveston, my family left Galveston.
Oh boy.
long about my junior year in college.
Sorry, I don't know what date that would be.
As I say, I'm miserable on dates.
I went to Kerrville.
Daddy went to work for the Veterans Hospital in Kerrville, you know, the tuberculosis hospital.
And so that's how I got to Kerrville.
My mother's still there.
My father's dead.
And I guess that about covers it as far as formal places to live.
picked up at UT as a freshman when you started your college at Gibbs.
Yeah, I went through Plan 2 here at the university and got my BA in Plan 2.
My English professor my freshman year was Harry Ranson, which shows how old I am, and a marvelous teacher, by the way.
And I think, if I'm not mistaken, I was the only
The only boy in the graduating class from Crystal City High School that went to the University of Texas.
Everybody else went to A&M.
So I was the maverick in the group.
And I got my BA here in Plan 2, which, as you may know, doesn't have a major.
And I got my MA here with a major in English and a minor in anthropology.
I wrote my MA thesis on science fiction.
Then I went to UCLA and took my PhD in anthropology.
Did you start out as an anthropology major on the master's level?
There were mentions, I think, in the letters that you were shooting in that direction.
No, not really.
The way it worked was that I'd really, I'd always been interested in anthropology.
I got interested in it from science fiction, and as you probably know, a great deal of science fiction deals with what really is a
conflict between cultures of one sort or another, even, you know, so you set it on Saturn, it's still the same deal.
So, and I was always interested in that.

When I got to university, my freshman year, I took a couple of courses in anthropology, and I, uh, I liked it, you know, liked it a lot, but I wasn't really hooked or anything, and I didn't take any more anthropology until my senior year, and a number of people had told me that
There was a professor on the campus that I really ought to take a course from before I left the university.
This was McAllister.
And I did.
I took it really to take McAllister, not to take anthropology.
And he was just one of these fabulous teachers, you know.
And really, from that time on, I was in anthropology.
But I was so committed for a variety of reasons, one reason I had so many hours, to English, that I went ahead and took my MA in English at the same time I was taking graduate work in anthropology.
And I actually taught English here for a while at Ransoms and Systems.
But I knew that wasn't what I wanted to do.
I found myself in my English classes talking about Cheyenne and Comanche and .
So I went to UCLA and took the PhD.
You had a pretty good variety of jobs while you were a student here, didn't you?
No, not really.
Didn't you have a radio program for a while?
Yeah, but that was later.
If my chronology isn't hopelessly off, it was after 1955 when I came back here to teach anthropology.
I hadn't finished my PhD, but I had everything but the dissertation.
And it was sometime after that that I got roped into
doing that disc jockey show on KHFI.
And we did it for a couple of years, as I recall, right up until the time, I think, that I left to go back to the University of California at Riverside to teach for a year.
But apart from that, there really wasn't much of anything.
Did you ever work for the American Statesman?
No.
Just thinking from the reporter.
No, I've written a couple of articles for them from time to time, but I never worked for them.
And really, as far as actual jobs are concerned, there's been almost nothing.
There was a period in Cincinnati, actually, where I worked for a record store, but not a long time ago.
That's pretty well covered that aspect of it.
Yeah, not that there's much to cover.
This type of article, I don't need much depth.
Or if I find I need it, I'll have to look back at you by letter.
Okay.
You started publishing when you were an undergraduate student here?
Is that right?
That sounds about right.
I know one of the letters is from your roommate at the time.
Really?
Commenting on a published story of yours.
He commented,
It's a great story now, this.
It's immaterial of Chaz behind me with a gun.
Isn't that funny?
I have no memory of that at all.
Who was it?
Do you remember Tom Toney?
I don't remember the name.
So it must have been.
So apparently you must have started when you... Well, actually, I started long before that.
That is, started writing.
It started before I ever left Cincinnati.
And I conned my folks into buying me a used Remington.
And I taught myself to type.
This is when I was so practically bedridden.
And I ground out all sorts of masterpieces and sent them in to a variety of editors.
And I'll never forget how kind most of them were.
You know, considering the quality of what I was doubtless sending them, they must have been pretty terrible.
And almost from the very beginning, I must have been about 14 when I began doing this, I hardly ever got just a form of rejection slip.
They'd always write me letters and say, this shows a lot of promise.
Keep trying.
Do this, that, or the other.
And it's something that meant a great deal to me.
And I kept it up.
All the time I was in Crystal City.
Despite my addiction to football and one thing and another, I wrote all the time.
Not prodigiously, but I was always writing something.
And so when I finally did connect, it wasn't a deal where I just sat down one day and wrote a story and somebody bought it.
Tony Boucher, actually.
But just that I had been writing ever since I was about 14 years old.
And to come back to your question, you know, I guess I must have been, I'm certain I was, because I know it was after we moved to Kerrville that I sold that first story, and I'll never forget it.
It was a story you probably are familiar with since you've researched me so thoroughly.
The Boy Next Door actually was a story that I wrote for Weird Tales and sent it to Weird Tales, and this was, you know,
toward the end of Weird Tales' existence, when they were not exactly doing what you'd call creative editing.
And I never got any response from them at all, just the manuscript back in the mail.
The magazine of fantasy and science fiction had just started up, and I'd read it and thought, boy, this is terrific.
Here's a guy that will probably appreciate my tremendous genius.
And he did.
You know, I was just floored.

When I got the letter, I can still remember it almost word for word, and the gist of it was he was apologizing because he could only pay $100 for it, and would that be satisfactory, and that they were having some financial trouble, so they couldn't pay right away.
I might have to wait a month or two, and you know, God, I'd have given them the story.
I'd have paid them.
to buy it, but yeah, that's when it started.
That's good.
That picked up a lot there.
I'm not mistaken, the introduction to The Boy Next Door mentions that this was the first one sold with the actual publication.
That's right.
Another story came first.
That's right.
After Tony bought, actually I should say McComas and Tony bought The Boy Next Door, I sold a story to Super Science.
And the editor, if I'm not mistaken, was a man named Jacobson.
I think it's the same guy that's editing Galaxy now who's come back out of whatever limbo he was in.
And he brought a story called The Land of the Lost Content, which actually was published before The Boy Next Door, but it was written after that.
That's interesting.
It was that Jacobson.
Yeah, it is.
He's done some interesting things with Galaxy.
Yeah, I'm sure he has.
I've just thumbed through it.
What's he done?
He's gone experimental for one time.
Meaning?
The new wave, the so-called new wave thing that you hear about, which leads logically to the next question.
Have you read much in the recent literature, and have you got any opinions on this new wave, quote, new wave, unquote?
Which I'm not sure what it is, frankly.
Well, first of all, I don't read science fiction.
any kind of science fiction as much as I used to because I just can't.
I don't have the time.
It doesn't bleed me.
It's not that I've lost interest.

It's just that I have so little time to read that I have to be fairly selective and therefore I don't feel that I'm as familiar with it as I ought to be to make some kind of halfway sane comment and I certainly don't want to
run down any writer that I really have not read.
On the other hand, I don't want to just dodge the question either.
Yeah, I've read some of it that I think could be classified as New Wave, Harlan Ellison, Spinrad, Delaney, who else?
There's somebody else that pops in that I recall reading, well I guess
Zalazny is sometimes classified in a new way.
I don't know exactly what to say about it.

I was amazed when I talked to Harlan Ellison when he came down and asked me for this story, but he more or less considered me part of the new way in the sense that a lot of the stuff that I was writing at the time that I wrote it was very non-traditional, including Shadows in the Sun, for example.
I guess the
The most honest thing I could say about it is that I've read some of it that I admire very much.
I think Bug Jack Baron, for example, is a damn interesting book.
And I understand what it is that they're trying to do.
The problem, from my point of view, is that it's just not on my wavelength.
quite know how else to put it.
I don't resent it.
I think it's a healthy trend as long as it doesn't crowd out every other type of writing.
I think you could be corny and say that Mr. Gernsback's mansion has many rooms, and I can't see why one or two of them couldn't be new with, for want of a better term.
You can't be static.
You can't stand still.

And I don't care how traditionalist you may think you are, you know, none of us wants to go back and write like Ray Cummings or Otis Adelbert Klein or somebody, or even Edgar Rice Burroughs, for that matter.
And it's really just a question of what direction are you going to move, and how much of what's been built up are you going to throw away?
I don't know if this makes any sense or not, but see, I come from the school, in broader terms, I think literature took a wrong turning with James Joyce.
And my, not that I don't admire Ulysses, I think it's a fascinating book, but I think it did more harm than good in the long run.
And my own preferences, I like novelists like Joseph Conrad, I like the early Hemingway,

things like The Sun Also Rises, and short stories like The Two-Hearted River, and things like that, partly because I'm a trout fishing nut, and you can see this book on the fly is that your microphone is sitting there.
And Steinbeck, despite all the criticism that's been leveled, I like a more traditionally based novel.
And I am, I fear, reactionary enough to still like stories with a beginning, a middle, and an end.
I don't know.
I remember I took an English course years ago in which the textbook was something called Tradition and Direction in the Modern Short Story.
And they began with four short stories, traditional stories, as examples of what not to do.
And I recall I liked all four of them better than anything else in the book.
But I would emphasize that I don't think it's a horrible development or anything of that kind.
It's quite obviously tied up with lots of broader changes in this culture and in writing in general.
And it's small wonder that so many of the younger writers are moving in that direction.
I think there's going to be a swing back the other way, eventually.
And I still, you know, given my druthers, I'd rather read Paul Anderson, but just the same, I like what they're doing.
First book, Mists of Dawn.
Were you contacted about this topic or did you orient it toward the youth market yourself?
No, uh, Mists of Dawn was written, uh,

shortly after I signed with my first agent, who was Scott Meredith, and Meredith had this contract with the Winston Company for a series of teenage-oriented, juvenile, whatever you want to call them, science fiction novels, and he asked me to write one, and asked me to write him an outline and a sample chapter, which I did, and that's how that thing was written.
the reviewers tended to criticize Mr. Dunn because of your characterization of the Neon development more than anything else.
They did.
That I don't remember.
It was interesting, given your anthropology, interesting background as to why you might have picked out this particular characterization.
To be honest, I don't remember.
It was a long time ago, and I don't remember
whether the specific topic was assigned to me or whether I picked it.
I don't know.
And I don't remember what the criticism was.
It got some good reviews.
It got good reviews.
In fact, the only negative point, generally, was this thing that Neanderthal wasn't...
There was no proof that he was the nasty old ogre that was in this picture.
Well, that's a fair criticism.
You can respond to it.
by saying that there wasn't any proof that he wasn't either.
Yeah, that's true.
And who knows?
But, you know, it's really not a factual error.
Not that I think factual errors are all that important.
It's a matter of case interpretation, and I think it's very definitely tied in with a number of other currents
No, there aren't any fashionable villains anymore.
You can't make an Indian a villain, you can't do this, you can't do that, and I guess you can't make a Neanderthal a villain either.
And I don't know, maybe all of those are too harsh.
It's probably a fair criticism.

There's also been a lot of discussion to the effect that the conflict, if there was one, between the Homo sapiens and the Neanderthals, and you see at the time I wrote this book, they were considered to be rather more different
than they are now.
That's probably what I'm going to say in your defense.
Yeah, they're both placed in genus Homo now, you know, with just separate species, presumably.
Prior to that, though, they were regarded as quite distinct.
And generally, the change has been that in the old days, there was this feeling there was kind of a knock-down, drag-out fight between the sapiens and the Neanderthals.
And apparently it probably wasn't that way.
It was more a matter of occupying the same ecological niche and one being more efficient than the other.

But you go back and read Missing Dawn, which I confess I have not done in a number of years, but I did only recall including some rather sympathetic passages about the Neanderthals too, including one that had something to do with a Neanderthal child.

And you've got to remember that the protagonist, the Missadon, is a young kid who suddenly finds himself back there, and chances are if Joe Neanderthal came walking through the door now, we would regard him with at least some trepidation.
Yes.
But it's a fair criticism.
I wouldn't object to that.
It's not nearly as annoying as some of the criticisms I've received, my favorite being from Kingsley Amos.

who criticized Shadows in the Sun, a great one, because he said, in effect, he thought it was a good book and all this, but the protagonist was utterly unbelievable, a six-foot-three anthropologist who lived in Texas.
I was guilty, as authors often are, of writing about myself, and I submit that I'm lots of things, but I'm not unbelievable.
That's curious.
Yeah.
Dick had mentioned several things that appeared possibly autobiographical in that book.
What, in Shadows in the Sun?
In the characters.

I don't know how much of the character actually is autobiographical, except for the... You know, if you happen to be a big man, it's easier to write about a big man, because that's what you've been all your life.
And, you know, he smokes pipe and things of this kind, but...
I guess there are other incidents in there that are autobiographical, too.
I don't even remember at this point.
This gets into the area of reading into a book many things that often weren't put there by the author, at least on a conscious level, which is one thing I wanted to try to avoid doing if I could.
I don't have the talent for it.
Well, you never know.
We talked about The Boy Next Door.
I don't know if you remember the story that clearly or not.

in effect, you know, it's modeled on an experience that I had as a child, where they had a radio program in Cincinnati, where every so often, if you accumulated enough coupons or whatever it was, you'd go down there and be interviewed on the air, and I was so turned off by all these saccharine interviews, you know, what have you been doing all week, Jimmy?
Yeah, I've been playing with my dog, and this, that, you know,
You know, I thought it would be fun to get a character who came in and really said something like, why all that?
I've been killing people.
But anyway, the character was named Jimmy Walls, and Jim Walls is my oldest friend.
He and I went through high school together, and he still lives here in Austin.
He runs a pier out here, I don't know if you're familiar with it, out on the lake.
And his mother got a hold of that story.

And she interpreted this to mean, you know, that I was really, literally saying that Jimmy Walls went out and killed people, and she went around to all the newsstands and bought copies and burned them and things of this kind, and just took it all dead seriously.
And so have a number of critics, by the way, talking about the profound point I was trying to make about the nature of this society and all that.
I mean, I was just having fun.
Well, excuse me.
I got the tone you were speaking of when I read the story.
much as watching the good old Uncle Jay show and waiting for the kids to come up and just lay one on them.
There's probably more that is autobiographical in Shadows in the Sun than in anything else.
After all, it's about Crystal City, and I was there.
It's a geographical location.
What, did I move it?
Oh, yes.
180 degrees the opposite direction.
I didn't remember.
You put it out.
to the west where you look at a map and there's nothing.
Not even a highway.
That was clever.
I did the same thing in the shores of another city.
Actually, I located it correctly, but I changed place names around so that if you actually went to whatever I called it in the book, you wouldn't find it there.
Mittaboni, I think I said it was in, and Mittaboni's cleaning the other end of Ucumban.
And I just did it, too.
I don't know why I did it.
No, not really.
I guess it's a device that's intended to indicate, look, this is based on a real place, but I don't really mean that when there are changes.
Yeah.
It's not literal.
Yeah.
There weren't any aliens in Crystal City.
Except me, darn.
I was the alien Yankee.
Hal and I have commented a couple of times on the
odds of any other pair of cities such as Carrizo Springs and Crystal City producing two Doctores of Anthropology?
Well, you talk about a fantastic coincidence department, you can extend it, but that the two of us would both be at the Biboonery and keep the odds.
That's true.
both having taken the same, or taking degrees at UT.
Just a whole chain.
Except the Claude went to Berkeley, and I went to UC Berkeley.
Ended up in the same stadium.
It's highly unlikely, to put it in that way.
Curiosity, which of your, maybe you've already answered this in print, pilgrimage is apparently one of your
favorite stories from what you said in Butcher and Boucher.
It's Boucher, or at least that's what he called it.
Oh, okay, Boucher.
Well, that's good to know.
Not his real name, you know.
But I like to pronounce things correctly when I can.
Well, I guess if you pronounce it correctly, it'd be Boucher.
Excuse me.
Someone butchers your first name terribly over at A&M, and I was trying to remember what they called you.
My first letter that came out in print was before I had this typewriter that was handwritten and nobody remarked on it.
